segments.text: This is an interview with Dr. William D. Van Ganten, head of the Department of Petroleum Engineering.
Today's date is October 23, 1981.
Let's begin, Dr. Van Ganten, by you telling us something about your early years in Rockdale and Corsicana.
You were born in Rockdale in 1934.
That's correct.
I was born in 1934, and I lived there until 1937, and my family moved to Corsicana.
And I grew up in Corsicana all the way through high school.
I graduated in 52 and came to Texas A&M at that time as an undergraduate student.
What was your father's occupation?
He was a oil field worker.
Worked in the woodbine field there in Corsicana and then later
W-O-O-D-B-I-N-E. One word?
Yes.
Woodbine Field in Corsicana.
And later moved to what's called the Shallow Field in Corsicana, which was right next to the town itself.
So I grew up living in the oil field.
And so I worked, of course, in the summers.
for the oil companies there.
All the way while I was in school here at A&M, I continued to work in the summers for the oil companies around Corsicana.
What recollections do you have of how the oil companies were operating in the forest when you were growing up?
Well, the operations around Corsicana were all independent oil operators, and it was a very hard time economically as far as the oil companies.
The oil

price of oil was very low and they were pretty much shoestring type operations and so there weren't any of the very few of the modern technological type procedures that we use today were employed there.
Did many of the wildcatters in that area make a lot of money out of this?
Not too many.
During the 40s was not a real boom economically and the companies were
of course, were in a bad condition before World War II, and they really didn't get in through the 40s.
They were still in fairly bad economic condition.
What was it that brought them out of this bad economic condition?
Well, really the oil company stayed in a fairly bad economic condition up until about 1973 when the Arab oil embargo occurred.
When the price of...

unsatisfactory financial condition up to this time well there was an abundance of oil and gas the there was more oil a lot more oil available than the need was and when you've got a surplus of anything the price is naturally not going to increase and so during that period of time there was due to inflation and different factors the
The cost of doing business was increasing, but the value of the oil wasn't increasing much, and so it put the companies in a squeeze.
You decided then to come to A&M to major in petroleum engineering?
That's correct.
Because as a boy you were around oil field work, and that's how you got your interest in petroleum?
That's right.
And you came here in 1952?
Came here to A&M in 1952.
which of course was in the class of 56.
I started out majoring in petroleum and then before I finished I decided that I also wanted to get a degree in geology.
So I got a dual degree which took five years, a BS in petroleum and a BS in geology.
Graduated in 1957.
Why did you have an interest in geology?
geology ties in directly with petroleum engineering, and really to be a good petroleum reservoir engineer, you need to have a good background in geology.
And then you stayed on here and got your advanced degrees here also?
Well, of course, in 57 I left and went to work with Magnolia Petroleum Company.
Where?
In Vanderbilt, which was down close to Victoria.
But Magnolia Petroleum Company became Mobile Oil Company with their reorganization in 1960.
So between 57 and 62, during that time, I worked for Magnolia for one year.
I went into the service, into the Air Force, spent two years in the Air Force.
came back to Magnolia, but this was in 1960.
When I came back, it was now Mobile.
They changed the name in the first part of 1960.
And I worked for Mobile for two more years before I came back to A&M to graduate school.
How long were you here for graduate school?
I was here in graduate school for four years.
Came in 62 and graduated in 66 with a PhD.
So I got a master's in petroleum engineering and a doctorate in petroleum engineering.
What was the topic of your research?
Research was in some of the fundamental properties of reservoir rock.
How to, dealing primarily with logging properties, on how to predict fluid saturations in the reservoir rock from well logs.
And then you became a...
I became a member of the faculty in 1966.
What rank?
I started out as an assistant professor.
Well, I guess I take it back.
In 1966, I became a research professor.
assistant or associate, I forget which it was, with the engineering experiment station.
And I kept that job for one year.
And then I joined the teaching staff in 67.
And you became department head when?
What are some of the duties that you perform as your best department head?
Well, as department head,
Of course, A&M has department head rather than department chairman, which the department head pretty much has the sole responsibility for the department.
I have to recruit faculty for the department to ensure that we have adequate faculty to teach the courses.
I prepare the budget for the department.
I administer the budget once it is approved.
I'm in charge of the personnel within the department, all the secretarial force, the bookkeeping force, reproducing section, plus the teaching faculty themselves.
How many people are under your supervision?
We've got 24 faculty members.
seven staff members under my supervision.
You became department head after the demand for patrol increased as a result of that embargo.
Discuss how the department changed between the time before that and after.
What an effect would this have on the department?
and look at the time that I came to the petroleum engineering, came back to graduate school in 62, we had very few students in petroleum engineering at that time.
I don't actually have the records here, but it's something like 100 students I would say total in petroleum engineering.
And from 62 up until
the time of the Arab oil embargo, there was very little increase in the number of students enrolled in petroleum.
I think in 1973 we had 140 students that were enrolled in petroleum engineering.
During that period of time, the cost of oil was very low.
we were producing, or we had the capacity to produce more oil than the country could actually utilize.
The country was importing a lot of oil at, or was importing oil at a very cheap price.
Cheaper than it could be produced here.
So there was very little incentive to develop our own petroleum resources, any additional petroleum resources.
So we were developing few of our own resources.
The demand was continuing to increase during that period.
Anytime that happens, you're going to get to a situation, finally, where the demand is going to exceed the production, exceed the supply, which occurred back before 1973.
But finally, by 73, we were very dependent on
imports of oil to satisfy our domestic needs.
So I guess the Arabs finally wised up to what was going on, the state of things, that they now were in the driver's seat, not the United States, as far as oil prices were concerned.
So they started to increase oil prices.
As they did this, everyone realized that we had not
done the exploration that we should have.
We had not developed the new reserves that we should have and now we were in a situation where we were relying very heavily on countries that we had no control over.
So beginning in about 73 with the embargo there was a big push in the United States to try to increase domestic production.
Well all during the 60s there was a big environmental push in the United States.
Everyone was

very much concerned about the environment no one really was worrying about our energy situation because they had sort of taken the energy situation for granted so there were there were a lot of restrictions that were placed on not only petroleum industry but all industries during the 60s trying to make sure that the environment was not damaged in any way and really a lot of these restrictions were not very well thought out
Well, anyway, beginning in about 73 then with the Arab oil embargo, there was a big push with the price going up that made more funds available to do exploration.
So there was a big push in this country to increase the level of exploration to try to find more oil ourselves.
When did it become economically feasible to increase the oil production in the United States?
Well, I think it became feasible in about 73.
when the price went up.
Up until that time, it really wasn't economical to do new expiration.
Your expiration cost.
How low the price was, or how much would the price have to bend to make it feasible to produce it?
Oh, that's hard to say.
You know, in 73, the price was about $3 a barrel.
And right now, it's $35 a barrel.
So in eight years, it has gone up more than a factor of 10.
Well, the oil does not cost the same amount.
Every barrel of oil you produce does not cost the same amount.
Some oil is harder to find than others.
So some of it's going to cost you more money than others does.
So when the price went from $3 a barrel to $6 a barrel, that made some fields economical to explore and produce.
Whether or not the field is economical depends on how hard it is to get the oil.
That's right.
how hard it is to get it out of the ground and how hard it is to find.
You know, how many dry holes you're going to have to drill before you find a producer.
Well, when did the situation start to improve after all companies started to increase?
Well, as far as with Texas A&M, as far as the petroleum department, we had an almost instantaneous increase in enrollment beginning in 73.
And it has been increasing every year since then.
Right now, we're averaging about 30% per year increase in enrollment in the department.
Last year, we had 1,050 students in the department.
This year, we've got 1,450 students in the department.
Here at A&M, it's about third in size, I think.
Mechanical engineering is probably the largest with about 1,800 students, and electrical engineering is the next largest, and then petroleum.
But as this demand for oil increased, so did the salaries paid to the petroleum engineers and where that happened.
That's right.
Can you discuss that, please?
Well, the petroleum engineering salaries have, for the past five years anyway,
have been averaging $200 to $300 a month more than the salaries paid to other engineers.
So that also has aided in the rapid growth in petroleum engineering here at A&M because we've had students that were majoring in other areas of engineering that have transferred over to petroleum.
Well, I can say last May, in May of 81, the average starting salary was $2,302 a month for a petroleum engineer.
And it was around $2,000 a month for the average of the other engineers.
And from what I can see now, the average starting salary for May of 82 is going to be somewhere in the range of $2,600 a month.
It's going up about 13%, 14% a year.
What was the salary level before the embargo in comparison to other fields of engineering?
Was it running less or the same?
Petroleum engineering was running the same as other fields of engineering up until the time of the embargo.
How do you assess the quality of the students that you're getting in this field?
The quality of the students that we're getting or the students that we're putting out?
Both.
Well, we have most knowledge of the students that we're putting out.
The students that we get, we really don't teach them many courses until their junior year.
So we have students that come into petroleum engineering, they're majoring in petroleum,

they're here for maybe here for two years and then transfer out to some other major and we never see them and they transfer out because they're not doing well in math and chemistry and physics and that sort of thing.
I would, in overall, I would say in the last five years that the quality of the incoming student probably hasn't increased any.
Has not increased any.
It's probably about constant.
Even though the
I think the SAT scores of our students have increased slightly.
I think as far as the university is concerned, they have increased some.
As far as our department is concerned, I think they're probably about constant.
And I think the quality of the student that we're producing is about the same as it was eight years ago.
has been hard to maintain that quality, because as your numbers increase, the students do not get as much individual attention.
And in a normal situation, you would expect the quality to deteriorate as the numbers increase.
I think right now, our senior class has about 175 students in it, and our junior class has about 190 students in it.
We've got a sophomore class that has about 400 and a freshman class that has about 600.
I think the quality of our junior and senior students is very good.
I think they're going to be excellent engineers when they graduate.
I can't really say to the quality of the freshman and sophomore students because we haven't had that much interaction with them.
What about female students?
Have you had an increase of women students?
Well, we have about 15% female in the department right now.
And we have had that same percentage for about the last three years, I'd say.
But of course, it wasn't too many years ago that we didn't have any females at A&M.
But we've sort of hit a constant situation now on the percentage of females enrolled in the department.
What do you think attracts females to petroleum engineering?
I think it's the same thing that attracts the males into it.
It's the good salary situation and the chance to do something meaningful in this day when we have an energy crisis.
Where are some of the places that petroleum engineers work?
Well, of course they work where the oil fields are and where the

the major offices of the oil companies, where they're located, and this is primarily in Texas, both the Gulf Coast area, East Texas, West Texas, in Louisiana, primarily along the coast and offshore, offshore Texas, New Mexico, the Rocky Mountain region with the new overthrust production,
California, Alaska.
Could you comment on the Alaska oil rush?
Well, I don't know whether I would call it the Alaska oil rush or not.
I mean, there was a major field discovered in Alaska, and that field has pretty well been developed.
And I think things are fairly stationary in Alaska now, you know, as far as the amount of operations that are going on.
It's a very nice oil field, and
Of course, I'd like to see us discover some more fields like that up there, but up to this point, that one field has been the only major field that's been discovered.
Has the Texas oil fields encountered any opposition from environmentalists, any organized opposition?
Well, I don't really know how to answer that.
We haven't had anybody marching at the oil fields like...
They did at Diablo Canyon Nuclear Plant.
We haven't had anything like that.
I think Texas is fairly receptive to energy exploration, production, refining, that sort of thing, because there's a large percentage of the people in the state make their livelihood from that.
But that doesn't mean to say that the oil companies don't really have to toe the line as far as the environment is concerned.
The Railroad Commission in the state of Texas
federal government have a set of regulations that the oil companies have to follow.
And it has made operations a lot more expensive than they were back in the days before they went into effect.
Let me ask you another question about your steel population.
What about the number of blacks?
Do you have a small number in your soap line?
Well, I guess I can answer that by saying Texas A&M has a small number.
I don't believe that there is any prejudice against a black student at Texas A&M or in petroleum engineering.
I think it's just a matter of the students that can qualify, that can make the grades, are treated just like they're all treated the same, whatever their color is.
Do you have any efforts to recruit blacks in this department?

really aren't out recruiting any kind of students we've got a lot of students that come to us in the last five years we haven't had to do a whole lot of recruiting ourselves most of our faculty members are 75% teaching 25% research and with the
Large increases in enrollment that we've had, this has taken its toll, I guess you might say, as far as research is concerned.
We are not doing as much research as we would like to be doing, although we're probably doing a lot more research than we were five years ago.
What are some of the research projects that are underway now that have recently been completed?
We have three or four areas that we're doing most of our research in.
One of these is numerical simulation.
We have our own computer here in the department.
And the numerical simulation of oil and gas reservoirs is a big area of research.
By this, we are able to predict how a reservoir is going to perform under different type conditions, doing it with a mathematical model.
Another area, a large area, is underground lignite gasification.

We've done laboratory experiments and we also have had several field tests involving the burning of lignite in the ground and recovering the energy from the lignite at the surface in the form of a gas.
This project is still an active project.
Of course our numerical simulation is still an active area.
We have a good bit of effort in
what's called enhanced recovery of oil and gas.
And this involves injecting of some type of fluid into the reservoir to get a higher recovery of the oil that's contained within the reservoir.
We also have a large area of expertise in stimulation of low permeability reservoirs, primarily the hydraulic fracturing of tight gas reservoirs.
Those four areas are our primary areas of research.
Most of the money for financing research comes from external support.
We, of course, work through the Texas Engineering Experiment Station, so we do get some state funding through the Experiment Station.

but we have external funding coming through, some of it through the Department of Energy, but I would say the bulk of it is coming from oil companies and energy companies that are investing in various research projects in the department.
Where are some of the schools your faculty members have come from?
Oh, we have members that have gone to Penn State, Oklahoma, Georgia Tech,
New Mexico Tech, Texas A&M, of course, University of Texas.
I guess that's about three-fourths of them have PhDs.
How does your petroleum engineering program at A&M compare with those at other universities?
Well, our program here is the largest petroleum department in the nation, as far as students are concerned.
And what the runner-ups are?
Oh, as far as number of students, University of Texas is second, and probably LSU or Tulsa would be third.
University of Tulsa?
Mm-hmm.
As far as the number of faculty, we have the largest faculty.
And here again, I would imagine Texas probably has the second largest faculty and probably Stanford has the third largest faculty.
Our department is rated by National Education Standards as the number one petroleum engineering department in the nation.
And it's rated both at the graduate level and the undergraduate level as number one.
How long has it been rated so far?
Oh, I'm aware of it for at least the last five years that it's been ranked that way.
Let's discuss the graduate program.
Are both Master of Science and Doctor of Philosophy degrees awarded?
We have Master of Science, Master of Engineering, Doctor of Philosophy, and Doctor of Engineering degrees.
Do you have any idea on the numbers enrolled in these programs?
We have, I think, 27 graduate students enrolled right now.
and that's about five at the doctorate level and the others at the master's level.
Are many of the graduate students foreign students?
Not too many.
We have probably a third of the graduate students that are foreign nationals.
We have a very small percentage of our undergraduate students that are foreign nationals, probably not over one or two percent.
Why do you suppose that is when some of these other engineering departments have pretty large numbers of foreign students?
I think the number of foreign students that we have is a function of our entrance requirements, that we have not given any financial support to any foreign nationals.
And the foreign nationals have to meet the same entrance requirement as our U.S. students.
And using that criteria, we have come up with about not too many foreign nationals in the program.
Do some of the other departments have more lenient requirements for law enforcement?
I don't know about that.
Do holders of advanced degrees in petroleum engineering command larger salaries than those with a bachelor's degree?
Yes, I would say that a master's degree probably gets a student about $200 or so a month more than what a bachelor's degree would get, beginning salary.
And we really don't have enough PhDs coming out.
They certainly command more than a master's, but I don't have a good handle on what the starting salary for a PhD is.
Is it difficult to convince students to obtain graduate degrees for high salaries they're offered with bachelor degrees?
Yes, it's very difficult to do that.
And we're making a fairly large push right now to try to increase the number of students that we have in the graduate program.
The industry needs more people with graduate degrees, and the universities need more teachers.
There's a very serious problem in the nation today trying to get engineering teachers, engineering faculty.
And one thing we've got to do is increase the number of graduate students.
Let's discuss the Department of Energy.
Do you think it's been successful in improving the nation's energy situation?
Well, I don't know what you mean by successful.
Are you talking about economically successful?
Well, yeah.
The Department of Energy is a very large federal agency, and any time you get a very large agency of any type, it's probably not very efficient.
And I would say that the Department of Energy has not been very efficient in increasing the supply of oil and gas in the country.
They certainly haven't been efficient in increasing the supply of oil and gas as far as increasing the energy supply.
I think they've been spending a lot of money on sources of energy that may pay off 20 years or 50 years from now.
They haven't spent a whole lot of money on
oil and gas research, which is needed in the short run.
There hadn't been as much money spent on oil and gas research.
I imagine they assumed that the oil companies would do the research.
Do you have any figures on how much oil production has increased, say, since 1973 in the United States?
I don't have any thing here.
I can look.
I can look those numbers up if you want me to give you some numbers.
You know, what we've been trying to do is to, as far as if you look at the reserves of oil and gas in the country, the reserves have been declining for a number of years.
And what we're trying to do is to get the reserves on the upswing again.
And the only way you get reserves on the upswing is by drilling more wells.
Back in the mid-50s, we were drilling about 55,000 wells per year.
During the late 60s, we were down to, in early 70s, we were down to about 25,000 wells per year, not even half as many as we were drilling in the 50s.
Well, now we're back up to the range of 60 or so thousand wells per year.
So I would expect to see the oil reserves to,
to follow this same trend and for us to see an increase in the amount of oil reserves that we have.
If you had control over public policy, what would you do to guarantee a large increase in oil production?
What could be done to do this?
Well, I think we need to have more tax incentives to increase, to increase exploration and increase enhanced secondary type recovery.
You know, we currently have the windfalls profits tax, which really is not a profits tax.
It is a direct tax off the top.
It doesn't make any difference whether you're making a profit or making a loss.
That tax still comes right off the top.

If it was actually a profits tax, well, then that would be a real incentive for the companies to take that money and try to invest it to develop other resources rather than just paying it in as taxes, whereas now they don't have that option.
They're taking really the heart of the income from the oil, and they're paying it to the government.
Well, then that's the reason a lot of taxes have opposed that one fall.
That's right.
The name is a misnomer.
It is not a profits tax.
It is just a tax right off the top.
So it is a deterrent to us becoming energy self-sufficient.
It was passed by Congress as a way of countering public attention to so-called huge increases in oil company profits.
I think that's right.
This tax is billed as a detriment.
Why is it that there hasn't been reports of oil companies, for instance, making the greatest profits ever here at this occasion?
Well, what you hear is percent increase over last year.
Well, that's not a very good way of looking at it.
We may have lost $1 million last year, and so we only lose $500,000 this year.
And that's a big increase.
So you can't go by percent increase in profits.
The oil companies were in a very bad financial situation before the air oil embargo.
Since that time, they've been increasing.
But you don't hear any of the reports
profits on investment if we aren't saying that you're making 5% on your investment.
In fact, if you look at the actual amount of money that the oil companies are making on their investment, if they took that same investment

down to the savings alone and invested it at 15% or whatever your federal money is these days, they would probably make more money off of that than they're making off of their investment in the oil industry.
But it's not reported that way.
It's reported as percent increase over last year.
Well, you think the windfall promise tax was passed for political reasons?
Sure it was passed for political reasons.
It was a way for the federal government to support the programs.
I doubt it.
I think the government is in a tight situation right now.
as far as trying to balance the budget.
To repeal the windfall profits tax would take away a large source of revenue to the federal government.
I don't really expect them to do that.
I think it should be done, but I don't really expect them to do it.
What about alternate sources of energy?
You mentioned earlier that the Department of Energy has invested a lot of money in other searches in this field.
Do you have any personal...
Any ideas personally on what other sources of fuel might be usable in the future?
Well, I think it's the standard things that are being mentioned now.
I think nuclear is an excellent source, and we need to get on with nuclear development and quit all the harassment and so forth of the companies that are trying to develop nuclear energy.
It isn't a matter of whether we want to or don't want to.
It's a matter that we've got to.
So the longer we put it off, the more protests and the more legal confusion there is, well, the longer it's going to be before we actually solve our problem.
What about would alcohol as a source propel cars?
Well, I think it has a very low potential.
If you look at
how much energy is required to produce the alcohol versus how much energy you get from the alcohol.
It takes almost exactly the same amount of energy to make it as you get from it.
So you're winding up where you began.
In order to make the alcohol, you've got to run it through a distillation.
Well, the energy that's required to distill the alcohol
It's the same amount that you get from the alcohol.
That's what keeps the price so high.
That's what keeps the price so high.
If you're going to distill it using natural gas, you're going to burn up more natural gas to make the alcohol than the BTU content that you get from the alcohol.
So why just not make the alcohol to begin with and use the natural gas for whatever you needed the energy for?
How much more efficient from that standpoint is it to produce gasoline as far as energy?
Oh...
It is tremendously more efficient.
I don't have those numbers, but I would estimate that you're only using maybe 25% of the energy to generate the gasoline that you actually get from the gasoline.
Whereas with alcohol, methanol, it takes 100%.

Now, if you can use some type of fuel like corn stalks or wood chips or something like that that you can't burn in a car to produce a liquid fuel that you can burn in a car, well, then you've accomplished something.
You've traded one type of energy for a more useful type of energy.
But as far as the energy balance itself is concerned, you wind up right where you began.
So that is not going to solve our energy problem.
What about producing energy from what's it called, shale?
Shale oil.
Shale oil.
That is a potential source of oil, of energy.
Here again, you're talking about a very expensive process.
And the cost of energy that we have today, like $35 a barrel for oil,
shale oil is doubtful as to whether it's economical at that cost.
What about the current glut on the oil market nationwide?
Do you have any response to that or reason for that being?
Well, I think the primary reason is the conservation that has been practiced in this country and other countries.
primarily with the automobile going from the large cars to the small cars, has decreased the requirements for gasoline.
The producing countries have pretty much continued to produce at their same rate, and our consumption has been lower.
Consequently, we get an excess of oil.
What effect do you think the deregulation of oil has had on the current prices?
I don't think it's had any effect on it.
Do you think it will have any effect in the long run?
I think it will have effect of better balancing supply and demand.
Do you expect gasoline prices to stay the same or change over the next several years?
I expect them to stay pretty much the same as long as we have a glut in the oil market.
Here again, you're looking at the forces of the market, the supply and demand situation.
If you've got more of a supply than you have a demand, well, you don't expect the prices to go up.
What impact do you think that the OPEC policies will have on our oil supply?
OPEC has a very large effect on our oil supply.

I really feel like that OPEC, that we haven't looked at it that way, but I feel that OPEC probably did us a big favor when they raised the price of oil, not only for the United States but for the whole world.
As long as you could get all the oil you wanted at $3 a barrel, you're not going to invest anything in developing new sources of energy.
Well, oil is not going to last forever.

And you don't want to run down to the situation where when you use up the last barrel of oil in the world and you have nothing else to take its place, you decide that maybe I better start working on a different source of energy.
So the price of oil needs to be in line
with the, what it's actually worth, I guess is what I'm trying to say.
Why were the Arabians selling this oil at less than they could have gotten for all these years?

They, I'm not sure they were selling it for less than what they could have gotten all these years because as I was saying a while ago, the United States had more oil capacity than they could actually produce back during those years when
The Arabians were selling it for $3 a barrel.
But it finally got to the situation where U.S. oil capacity started to decline, where we were dependent on them, where they did have control of the market.
Before that, they didn't have control of the market.
We had control of the market.
Do you think this controversy over the selling of the AWACS planes to Saudi Arabia is tied in with oil industry, or do you think it's strictly a foreign policy issue?
Well, I think it's a foreign policy issue.
Of course, I support very strongly the U.S. selling AWACS to Saudi Arabia.
Saudi Arabia is a very good friend of this country.
And I think if we don't sell it to the Saudis, it will be interpreted by them as an unfriendly act on our part, which certainly will not be in our national interest.
Do you have any idea how much oil we're getting from Saudi Arabia?
Oh, I think we're getting roughly half of our imports come from Saudi Arabia.
A very large, substantial portion of our imports.
Do you think the sale is rejected by the Congress?
It appears it will be, and this one could affect our oil imports.
I don't think there's any question about it.
It's just one factor.
I'm not saying it's the only factor, but Saudi Arabia has looked to the United States for protection.
They have looked to the United States for leadership over the years.
Saudi Arabia is very much Americanized, so to speak.
I've been to Saudi Arabia for the last two years on trips, and they're our friends, I guess is the way I'd put it.
And like I said a while ago, if we don't sell them these AWAC planes, we are not being their friends.
We are not treating them as we should treat our friends.
And I think we're going to have to pay the consequences.
Do you think the main opposition to the sale of these planes is politically as a way to embarrass Reagan, or do you think it's because of the power of the Jewish lobby?
Oh, I think it's because of the power of the Jewish lobby.
Do you have any ideas on the long-range energy picture facing the United States in the 1980s?
I don't think it's going to get a whole lot better.
You see the current situation standing itself for a while.
For a long while.
Do you think the gasoline prices are going to remain about where they are for how much longer?
It's hard to say.
I think they'll remain this way for another couple of years anyway, unless we have something
You know, if we have a war that breaks out in the Middle East and that supply is cut off where there isn't an oil glut, well, the prices can change next month.
But if the world situation in the Middle East stays as it is right now, I would expect oil prices to stay constant for the next couple of years.
You know, we've gone almost a year now with prices constant.
Anything else you can say?
I'm just about to run out of questions.
Anything that we need to touch on?
I think that the petroleum engineering curriculum is a very good curriculum for a young person in that he is trained how to drill wells, how to produce fluids from wells,
how to separate those fluids, process them at the surface, ship them down pipelines to the consumer.
He learns about fluid flow through porous media.
He learns about geology and economics.
With that background, he can be a petroleum engineer and produce oil and gas.
He could produce groundwater just as well.
He could produce geothermal energy just as well.
He could do mineral leaching, mineral processing just as well.
He could work in institute lignite gasification or coal gasification just as well.
So it isn't a degree that is...
